audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check; justify one inference with a quote.

learning_objectives: Draw conclusions supported by the text.
Cite the words that justify the inference.

structure.title: Inferences
objectives: State the inference in plain language first.
Point to the exact words that justify it.

lecture_script.script: An inference is a justified conclusion. Ask: If this sentence is true, what must also be true?
‘Checks the door twice’ suggests worry about security-so I infer caution, not forgetfulness without evidence.
Hold up the letter for the option that is supported without adding unstated claims.

worked_example.passage: Hearing thunder grow nearer, Lina moved metal chairs indoors before locking the garden gate.
worked_example.question: What can be reasonably inferred about Lina?

options.B: She anticipates risk and prevents damage.
options.C: She plans to sell the chairs.

worked_example.explanation: Her preventive actions show anticipation of risk.

practice_set.passage: When the auditorium lights dimmed, the presenter waited until whispers faded, then began.
practice_set.question: What is the most reasonable inference?

options.C: The presenter sought full attention first.

homework: Write a one-sentence inference for three mini-passages and cite words that support it.
Revise one overreaching inference to remove speculation.
Complete four inference items and explain one elimination.
